image.altText: Shark attack victim Tod Gendle.

items.synopsis: The surfer presumed to have been killed in a shark attack on South Australia's west coast has been identified as Tod Gendle, with his family releasing a statement expressing "thoughts and prayers" for those who witnessed the incident.

title.children: Deadly shark attack victim named as Tod Gendle, as family releases statement

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: Jason De Ieso was shot dead at his crash repair business in Adelaide's northern suburbs in 2012, with police and prosecutors arguing he was the accidental victim of a feud between rival bikie gangs.

title.children: Six of seven men found guilty of murder of Jason De Ieso file notice to appeal convictions

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: Erin Patterson, who cooked a mushroom lunch in late July suspected of resulting in three people's deaths, faces charges including murder and attempted murder.

title.children: Police lay murder charges over mushroom deaths after Erin Patterson arrested

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks solemn in a close-up shot.

items.synopsis: In their strongest comments since the outbreak of the Israel-Gaza war, the prime minister and foreign minister warn Israel to abide by the rules of war, saying Israeli and Palestinian lives matter, and the international community will not tolerate innocent deaths.

title.children: 'Every Palestinian life matters, like every Israeli life matters': Government urges Israel to observe rules of war

image.altText: A young boy and man kneel on cushions in front of a small shrine.

items.synopsis: Kazuhiro Suzuki is Japan's ambassador to Australia. He is also the son of a trained kamikaze pilot. His family history tells the story of Japan's ruinous embrace of empire, and its transformation in the decades since.

title.children: Ambassador Suzuki carries the weight of his father's past as a kamikaze pilot. He says it tells us about Japan and Australia today

image.altText: Protesters outside South Australia's parliament during a teachers' strike.

items.synopsis: South Australian public school teachers vote to strike again next week if the state government does not increase its pay offer — but the union says students preparing for Year 12 exams will not be adversely impacted.

title.children: Teachers vote to strike amid SA exams, if no pay deal reached

image.altText: A woman with a serious expression stands in front of posters on a wall

items.synopsis: South Australia's Training Centre Visitor Shona Reid says since she was appointed last year, her office has taken a "deep dive" into records to uncover the extent of self-harming at the state's youth justice centre. Warning: This story contains references to self-harm.

title.children: 'A very lonely, scary place to be': Concerns for child welfare in SA youth detention

image.altText: An aerial photograph showing a breakwater and jetty near a sandy bay

items.synopsis: Councils along South Australian coastlines will meet in a bid for planning consistency to mitigate sea level rise and effects of a warming climate.

title.children: Coastal protections for breakwaters, jetties and dunes a top priority in council mitigation plans as climate warms

image.altText: A man and three women posing with their awards in front of an oval

items.synopsis: Environmental scientist and activist Timothy Jarvis says he hopes his new title as South Australia's 2024 Australian of the Year would inspire people to help stop climate change in any way they can.

title.children: 'Up to each of us to make a difference': SA Australian of the Year announced

image.altText: The Wiggles 2022

items.synopsis: The children's music group says the City of Bunbury's decision to play the song on a loop to stop people from sleeping rough at a public bandstand runs counter to the message of their music.

title.children: The Wiggles slam regional city's use of 'Hot Potato' to deter homeless people

image.altText: A middle aged man with short greying hair stands in front of a backdrop displaying the Australian Parliament House flagpole.

items.synopsis: The treasurer admits that Australia is on track to fall short of its climate targets without more money invested, quicker construction of renewables projects, and better regulation.

title.children: Treasurer Jim Chalmers concedes Australia risks missing its climate targets

image.altText: A man looks skyward as he carries a wounded girl down a street as a man and boy flank him

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong reiterates a call for a "humanitarian pause" to deliver supplies to people in Gaza, adding Australians who have fled to Egypt are in good health.

title.children: Wong calls for 'humanitarian pause' in Gaza, says Israel must follow 'rules of war'— as it happened

image.altText: A brick wall says Treaty and has handprints above a painted Aboriginal flag.

items.synopsis: Indigenous elder Mick Gooda says the backlash in Queensland after the failure of the Voice referendum has been greater than he expected.

title.children: 'Takes the wind out of you': Mick Gooda says backlash after failed Voice referendum greater than expected

image.altText: a volunteer firefighter stands among a group of colleagues listening to a briefing. he's wearing a bandana on his head

items.synopsis: Conditions have eased today, but there are still a multitude of bushfire warnings in southern Queensland, where dozens of homes have been lost.

title.children: Focus remains 'protection of life and property' as interstate help arrives to support fire crews in Queensland

image.altText: An outdoor staircase in a city area ablaze amid buildings

items.synopsis: The Arson Squad is investigating the cause of a bushfire that burnt close to apartments in central Perth near the popular Jacob's Ladder staircase in Kings Park.

title.children: 'I've never seen anything like that': High-rise residents flee central Perth fire

image.altText: A small brown brick house

items.synopsis: A government-owned house that has been empty for seven years in the small town of Kalangadoo will be offered to other public servants and the town's police station will close.

title.children: Housing crisis sparks action to rent out long-vacant house reserved for police

image.altText: Two men stand side by side leaning on the front of a small plane on a runway.

items.synopsis: It took two years and an unconventional job package, including pilot training, but this outback town once again has a doctor on duty.

title.children: Global recruitment drive lands a much-needed GP for outback SA town Wudinna

image.altText: A pair of regent parrots on a stick with slightly different colouring.

items.synopsis: The regent parrot population is suffering, but a group of researchers who specialise in working out what's wrong with rare and beautiful creatures could make the difference.

title.children: This beloved parrot is in decline in SA's Riverland. Enter the 'difficult-bird' research team

image.altText: a volunteer life saver looks out over coogee beach on a hot sydney day

items.synopsis: Giant eddy currents in the sea spread heat. But if trapped in place, they can cause marine heatwaves deadly to sea life. And there's a big one shaping up off Sydney right now.

title.children: A monster eddy current is spinning into existence off the coast of Sydney — and it could be trouble

image.altText: A man dressed as Santa wearing a face mask.

items.synopsis: The Director of Communicable Diseases at NSW Health has warned a COVID wave could peak at Christmas for the third year in a row.

title.children: Another 'COVID Christmas' on the cards thanks to fresh wave, experts warn

image.altText: Danny and Michael sitting down looking down at a screen

items.synopsis: Screen Australia has released its latest Drama Report, which shows in part how Australian creators are reaching tens of millions of people around the world by tapping into audiences who have an appetite for content not being picked up on mainstream channels.

title.children: 'It's where the most viewers are': Australian content reaching tens of millions around the world

image.altText: Celine Dion smiles at Montreal Canadiens head coach Martin St-Louis

items.synopsis: The Canadian singer was seen at an ice hockey game on Monday night, with fans happy to see the star joking and laughing after she revealed her rare neurological illness.

title.children: Smiling Celine Dion makes rare public appearance almost a year after revealing stiff person syndrome diagnosis

image.altText: A person wearing a winnie the pooh costume waves as they walk past cars down a busy street at night.

items.synopsis: Halloween revellers gathered in central Shanghai late on Tuesday night, with some dressing in costumes that poked fun at Chinese authorities in a rare showcase of free expression.

title.children: Halloween revellers party in Shanghai, some wearing costumes seen as a protest against China's policies

image.altText: A man crouches on a hospital floor looking at people under silver blankets

items.synopsis: In Gaza's busiest hospital, doctors do what they can to treat a tidal wave of desperate patients injured in Israeli air strikes. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: Sewing needles, dishwashing liquid and kids on the floor: The unthinkable horrors of Gaza's hospitals

image.altText: Abdullah, pictured with his grandkids.

items.synopsis: Twenty Australians have successfully fled Gaza as 65 remain registered to leave, according to foreign affairs officials.

title.children: 'You can go, she has to stay': Australian man returns to Gaza after wife denied border crossing

image.altText: Logo of Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital

items.synopsis: A man has been seriously injured and three other people have been taken to hospital after a dog attack north of Brisbane.

title.children: Four people taken to hospital after dog attack in Morayfield, north of Brisbane

image.altText: Irma Palasics

items.synopsis: A man charged over the 1999 killing of Canberra woman Irma Palasics during a violent home invasion pleads not guilty to murder as he is charged with five new offences.

title.children: Man charged with murder of Canberra grandmother pleads not guilty, charged with five new offences

image.altText: Andrew O'Keefe wears suit and tie walks on Sydney street

items.synopsis: Andrew O'Keefe gives a detailed account of the lead-up to an alleged incident that ended with the 52-year-old being charged with a number of offences, including common assault.

title.children: Former TV host Andrew O'Keefe tells court woman's arm scratches were self-inflicted

image.altText: A gas platform in the Timor Sea.

items.synopsis: An emergency injunction granted to a Tiwi Islands traditional owner by the Federal Court has halted construction of the project's underwater gas export pipeline for several weeks.

title.children: Santos ordered to pause construction on $5.6b Barossa project, hours before works due to start

image.altText: A view of the rubble of buildings hit by an Israeli airstrike.

items.synopsis: Israeli forces claim to have killed another Hamas commander in their second strike on Gaza's largest refugee camp in two days, as a first group of civilian evacuees from Gaza — including 20 Australians — escapes into Egypt.

title.children: Israel claims Hamas commander killed in second strike on Jabalia refugee camp in two days

image.altText: A man in a suit walking along a city street.

items.synopsis: A Perth police officer is sentenced to two years in jail for assaulting a woman during an arrest in which she was forced to the ground, dragged across the floor and kicked in the foot.

title.children: 'You're out of line': Police officer jailed after assaulting woman during violent arrest

image.altText: entrance to shopping stor with Kmart signage and customers walking and with trolleys by customer service desk

items.synopsis: Australian retailer Kmart has paid a $1.3 million fine for having sent more than 200,000 marketing emails to people who had already unsubscribed.

title.children: Kmart slapped with $1.3 million fine for sending marketing emails to customers who opted out

image.altText: An Australian batsman lets his bat drop to the ground in disappointment after being dismissed in a match.

items.synopsis: Australia suffers another blow ahead of their Cricket World Cup clash against England in Ahmedabad, with Mitch Marsh leaving the Aussie camp for personal reasons.

title.children: Mitch Marsh leaves Cricket World Cup for personal reasons

image.altText: A man in a lab coat standing in a white room next to a small bar fridge, making a thumbs down gesture

items.synopsis: Consumer advocacy group CHOICE calls out "the very worst products and services" it found this year.

title.children: This fridge 'doesn't make things cold'. It's won a Shonky Award, just like Coles and Woolworths

image.altText: A white blonde woman and a white brunette man, both in their 30s, stand intimately looking at each other in a desert.

items.synopsis: The third feature from Australian director Garth Davis sets a high dramatic bar for this adaptation of Iain Reid's 2018 novel, but it unintentionally teeters into comedy.

title.children: Saoirse Ronan and Paul Mescal star in this R-rated sci-fi romance filmed in regional Victoria
